node.body:
Version: 1.84.0 (user setup)
Commit: d037ac076cee195194f93ce6fe2bdfe2969cc82d
Date: 2023-11-01T11:29:04.398Z
Electron: 25.9.2
ElectronBuildId: 24603566
Chromium: 114.0.5735.289
Node.js: 18.15.0
V8: 11.4.183.29-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22621

Extensions: C/C++ VS Code official extension

Sometimes (its hard to understand when it was started and under what circumstances), VSCode with clang-tidy 17 based code analysis, shows code warnings problems only for those lines that was recently changed, even after saving the file. The old lines remains without warnings highlighting, even though they have pretty same code problems.
You can even change the old line somehow, leaving the issue, and the warning will appear. But once you do Ctrl-Z, or just manually delete your changes, then save file again, the warning disappears, even though the actual issue remains.
If I press "Fix this readability-identifier-naming-problem" in popup, only recently changed lines will be fixed. The old lines remain unchanged.
As many lines I edit, as many problems shown, if they all actually have some code analysis issues, so it shouldn't be that 100- or 50- threshold problem.
Commands like "Reset intellisense database", "Restart intellisense for active file" - all dont give any effect on the problem.
If I run command "Clear all code analysis problems", the problems become cleared. Then after running "Run code analysis on active file", problems again shown but still only for recently changed lines. I turned the logging verbosity of extensions to Debug and have seen this:

Checking for syntax errors: C:\Users\\...\myawesomesourcefile.c
Queueing IntelliSense update for files in translation unit of: C:\Users\\...\myawesomesourcefile.c
idle loop: reparsing the active document
sending 1 changes to server
Checking for syntax errors: C:\Users\\...\myawesomesourcefile.c
Queueing IntelliSense update for files in translation unit of: C:\Users\\...\myawesomesourcefile.c
Error squiggle count: 0
Update IntelliSense time (sec): 0.587

It looks like only changes are sent to the server, thus only changes are sent to clang-tidy. Is it correct?
If yes, the case where we lost "zero coordinate" by working only with changes may occur, and clang-tidy may lost old context.

nodes.body:
Please file this bug with the C++ extension. https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-cpptools
/causedByExtension

This issue is caused by an extension, please file it with the repository (or contact) the extension has linked in its overview in VS Code or the [marketplace](https://aka.ms/vscodemarketplace) for VS Code. See also our [issue reporting guidelines](https://aka.ms/vscodeissuereporting). If you don't know which extension is causing the problem, you can run `Help: Start extension bisect` from the command palette (F1) to help identify the problem extension.

Happy Coding!

node.title: Code Problems shown only for recently changed lines, but not for old ones.

nodes.body:
Thanks for reporting this issue! Unfortunately, it's hard for us to understand what issue you're seeing. Please help us out by providing a screen recording showing exactly what isn't working as expected. While we can work with most standard formats, `.gif` files are preferred as they are displayed inline on GitHub. You may find https://gifcap.dev helpful as a browser-based gif recording tool.

If the issue depends on keyboard input, you can help us by enabling screencast mode for the recording (`Developer: Toggle Screencast Mode` in the command palette). Lastly, please attach this file via the GitHub web interface as emailed responses will strip files out from the issue.

Happy coding!

nodes.body:
Hi @brauliobarahona

1. Does the crash happen immediately for you?
2. Could you run `code --verbose` and then paste the output around when the crash occurs?
3. Could you create and upload a crash report, following the guide at https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Native-Crash-Issues?
Try enabling SIP if it hasn't been enabled yet! This fixed it for me.

node.title: Crash on save

node.body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

My suggestion is to add the functionality to be able to *move* installed extensions from a profile to another. I believe this would facilitate the user in better organizing their workflow. 
By "*moving an extension*" I mean to uninstall it in the current profile and install on the other (or, as a different approach, mark it as pending for install at next profile launch). 

**Use Case**:
I have installed ~100 extension over the course of time, half of which are disabled.
<sup>*(Note: VS Code was first released 8 years ago (2015). The Profiles functionality was introduced recently, in [VS Code 1.76 (February 2023)](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_76).*</sup>
With my suggested feature it would be possible to easily batch move all related extensions (e.g. all JS/TS, C#, C++, Python, Java, etc) to a separate profile.

Thank you

Using VSCode 1.84 on Win11
node.title: To be able to move installed extensions from a profile to another

node.body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Bug #25596 was closed saying to use the "Open Next Editor" setting in Code. This option has been removed from Settings and I am no longer able to Cmd+Tab between open tabs, only alternate between the two most recent tabs. This is broken behavior and needs to be fixed.
node.title: Add back "Open Next Editor" option (Bug 25596)

node.body:
Hi,

References view is not respecting `enablePreview` settings.
It makes References view inconsistent with other view like e.g. Search.

In e.g. Search view when we are navigating with keyboard (up, down arrows) then preview editor pops up.
Below video shows the problem.

[screen-recording(3).webm](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/assets/20733636/7fa41d1f-4146-4e4d-b104-f7efe7db708d)
node.title: References view should respect enablePreview

fix width of composite bar

commit.message:
terminal: allow the find widget to work in detached terminals

- Abstracts some methods to an `IAnyTerminalInstance` interface that
  is common between attached and detached terminal instances.
- Some minor changes in the find contribution to make it work with
  detached instances after that.
- Make the find widget track the `activeFindWidget` since commands
  previously depended on the active terminal, which is not tracked for
	detached terminals (the alternative would be making the active
	terminal instance tracker also track detached terminals)

And then it 'just works' in the test results terminal

node.title: terminal: allow the find widget to work in detached terminals
